03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Aegon I Targaryen was a warrior of renown, the greatest Conqueror in the history of Westeros, yet many believe his most significant accomplishments came during times of peace. The Iron Throne was forged with fire and steel and terror, it is said, but once the throne had cooled, it became the seat of justice for all Westeros.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon I Targaryen was renowned for forging something greater than himself. He cooled six realms of deadly fire with his sword made from steel, he rode a dragon that had terrorized Westeros for centuries, and on the Iron Throne of Westeros he sat. The significance of his legacy stretched to the far ends of the realm, and his accomplishments are still remembered as one of the greatest in history.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon I Targaryen was one of the greatest Targaryens to ever reign. With his fire and steel, he forged a renown for himself that extended far beyond Westeros and into the most distant corners of the world. His loyal subjects could see him in their dreams; his enemies trembled at the sound of his name in terror. To commemorate this, Aegon constructed the Iron Throne with a thousand swords cooled by dragonfire - a significant symbol recognized as one of his greatest accomplishments during his rule.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The reconciliation of the Seven Kingdoms to Targaryen rule was the keystone of Aegon I’s policies as king. To this end, he made great efforts to include men (and even a few women) from every part of the realm in his court and councils. His former foes were encouraged to send their children (chiefly younger sons and daughters, as most great lords desired to keep their heirs close to home) to court, where the boys served as pages, cupbearers, and squires, the girls as handmaidens and companions to Aegon’s queens. In King’s Landing, they witnessed the king’s justice at first hand, and were urged to think of themselves as leal subjects of one great realm, not as westermen or stormlanders or northmen.
events: reconciliation of the Seven Kingdoms to Targaryen rule
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon I was determined to bring former enemies into the fold in order to reconcile the Seven Kingdoms to Targaryen rule. He made great efforts and travelled far across Westeros, urging people at every corner of the realm, from Duskendale and Gulltown to Evenfall Hall and Tarth, to serve him. His famed courage shown through fire and steel had cemented his renown even before he sat on the Iron Throne with Rhaenys by his side. As people witnessed his greatness first-hand, many were encouraged by Good Queen Alysanne's leal pardons or King Jaehaerys' conquests during The Great Council of Harrenhal, so much so that Aegon received gifts from all across - from a Redwyne girl sending Aegonfort's stones for building-up Dragonstone castle, or a bastard born man gifting Visenya's Hill for turning it into a royal residence - as a token of their former loyalties soon turned loyalty to House Targaryen.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon I Targaryen made great efforts to promote the reconciliation of the Seven Kingdoms to Targaryen rule, which were encouraged by his loyal subjects across Westeros. Those who witnessed Aegon's cunning and courage first-hand served him ururedly as he forged a realm greater than any other before or since. Even as former enemies like House Lannister's eldest son, Loren Lannister's heir Loren, bowed down in reverence, nobles likeEvenstarof Tarth King Jaehaerys Alton Celtigar and Archmaester Lyonce shared their tales of Aegon's fire and steel with those who had not yet flourished under his reign of renown. Tall septons referred to him as "the greatest" while even distant corners of the former seven kingdoms witnesssed how significant an impact targarian rule had on them - terrorized yet utterly transfixed by their new ruler - and urged loyalty onto Aegon I all over again.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The Targaryens also brokered many marriages between noble houses from the far ends of the realm, in hopes that such alliances would help tie the conquered lands together and make the seven kingdoms one. Aegon’s queens, Visenya and Rhaenys, took a special delight in arranging these matches. Through their efforts, young Ronnel Arryn, Lord of the Eyrie, took a daughter of Torrhen Stark of Winterfell to wed, whilst Loren Lannister’s eldest son, heir to Casterly Rock, married a Redwyne girl from the Arbor. When three girls, triplets, were born to the Evenstar of Tarth, Queen Rhaenys arranged betrothals for them with House Corbray, House Hightower, and House Harlaw. Queen Visenya brokered a double wedding between House Blackwood and House Bracken, rivals whose history of enmity went back centuries, matching a son of each house with a daughter of the other to seal a peace between them. And when a Rowan girl in Rhaenys’s service found herself with child by a scullion, the queen found a knight to marry her in White Harbor, and another in Lannisport who was willing to take on her bastard as a fosterling.
events: queens took a special delight in arranging matches-marriage between noble houses - double wedding between house blackwood and bracken. rowan girl found with child by scullion
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon and his sisters Visenya and Rhaenys brokering matches across the Seven Kingdoms to ensure their rule was secure. Aegon took a special delight in sealing these matches as it ensured loyalty from each of the seven kingdoms. Notable matches made included the double wedding between House Blackwood and House Bracken, as well as another one, involving Lord Ronnel Arryn of The Eyrie with a Redwyne girl, at The Arbor. Torrhen Stark of Winterfell married an Evenstar of Tarth in a lavish ceremony at White Harbor for all rivaled to see. Queen Visenya then arranged for marriages between noble families far and wide; from Lannisport to Casterly Rock to Tarth, House Corbray, Hightower and Harlaw were all sealed by alliance through betrothals brokered by her own hands. In addition, a Rowan girl was found with child by a scullion shortly after this flurry of marriage was arranged; she had been taken into fosterling by Orys Baratheon's house but she would remain forever aloof from her betrothed due to the bastard she bore.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Visenya and her queenly sisters took a special delight in arranging matches-marriage between noble houses. Aegon had recently sealed a reconciliation of the Seven Kingdoms to Targaryen rule, ushering in a new era of peace and prosperity, so were encouraged by their father in the many betrothals that were arranged. A double wedding was arranged between House Blackwood and Bracken with a Redwyne girl matched with Loren Lannister's eldest son. The Evenstar of Tarth, Ronnel Arryn, Torrhen Stark's daughter Rowan girl even found herself with child by a scullion on one such forged connection far across the Seven Kingdoms. Lords like Corbray, Hightower Harlaw and great septons from all corners of the realm witnessed these reconciliations as they sought to end former centuries old enmity of rivals while young Aegon Targaryen III was yet an infant fostered at Winterfell with his heir older brothers; princes Aenys and Jaehaerys I.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Though none doubted that Aegon Targaryen was the final authority in all matters relating to the governance of the realm, his sisters Visenya and Rhaenys remained his partners in power throughout his reign. Save perhaps for Good Queen Alysanne, the wife of King Jaehaerys I, no other queen in the history of the Seven Kingdoms ever exercised as much influence over policy as the Dragon’s sisters. It was the king’s custom to bring one of his queens with him wherever he traveled, whilst the other remained at Dragonstone or King’s Landing, oft as not seated on the Iron Throne, ruling on whatever matters came before her.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: The good Queen Alysanne had long exercised soft reign from King's Landing, traveling far and wide to all the seven kingdoms in order to understand their customs. In particular, the actions of Aegon and his sister queens Rhaenys and Visenya were widely doubted by common folk across the realm as their weddings with prominent houses took too much delight for them. A special double wedding was arranged between House Blackwood and Bracken; then a match between a Redwyne girl and Lord Edmyn Tully was sealed – matched by Evenstar of Tarth to House Corbray while Torrhen Stark married into House Hightower - though these affairs were easily overshadowed when it transpired that Rowan girl had been found with child by a mere scullion at Casterly Rock. With much secrecy required, Grand Maester Gawen ensured that tiny bastard fosterling was taken care of away from noble eyes at White Harbor before being sent for adoption to distant relatives at The Arbor.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon Targaryen, Visenya and Rhaenys were determined to bring unity and solidarity to the Seven Kingdoms as they traveled from far ends of the realm, visiting places like Dragonstone and King's Landing. They brokered a number of matches between noble houses in order to strengthen their rule. Good Queen Alysanne, alongside King Jaehaerys I had doubted Aegon’s abilities when he first began ruling, though over time his power was exercised successfully across much of the Seven Kingdoms - sealing many peace treaties with kingdoms old enemies. In particular, he arranged double weddings between House Blackwood and Bracken making a match that would go on for centuries while also fostering an illegitimate child of one Redwyne girl and another Rowan girl. This final act unified not just warring houses but custom towards illegitimacy within the seven kingdoms one by one.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Though Aegon had designated King’s Landing as his royal seat and installed the Iron Throne in the Aegonfort’s smoky longhall, he spent no more than a quarter of his time there. Full as many of his days and nights were spent on Dragonstone, the island citadel of his forebears. The castle below the Dragonmont had ten times the room of the Aegonfort, with considerably more comfort, safety, and history. The Conqueror was once heard to say that he even loved the scent of Dragonstone, where the salt air always smelled of smoke and brimstone. Aegon spent roughly half the year at his two seats, dividing his time between them.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: During Aegon's reign, the designated seat of power was moved from Dragonstone to a more comfortable and safe location. King’s Landing had much historical importance since it was close to his conquest in the War for Seven Kingdoms one. Aegon had several castles built surrounding this area, such as "Aegonfort" between King's Landing and Dragonmont, which he spent much time installing himself and had to be ten times reinforced with its walls lined with salt. As part of his love for royal customs, he even changed its name from Smoky Castle to "Aegonfort." In addition, nearly all the resources were spent on constructing a castle at Dragonstone. An enormous smoky tower known as Dragonmont now stands tall there where Aegon Targaryen once ruled over Westeros with Rhaenys and Visenya by his side before reluctantly being doubted by some of his own people.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon's designated seat of power, Aegonfort at King's Landing, was quickly becoming established as he installed smoky red bricks and ten times more comfortable furnishings. As he spent the necessary funds to make sure that the castle was safe and historical enough for a royal family, its salt-and-smokey brimstone aroma wafted between every corner announcing his presence there. It gave him a feeling of love and comfort knowing that his children now had a much safer place to live than Dragonstone would provide them. Naturally, by the final hours of ruling from both Dragonmont and Old Oak before traveling to King’s Landing, much time and custom had already been exercised in an attempt to restore peace throughout the Seven Kingdoms.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The other half he devoted to an endless royal progress, taking his court from one castle to another, guesting with each of his great lords in turn. Gulltown and the Eyrie, Harrenhal, Riverrun, Lannisport and Casterly Rock, Crakehall, Old Oak, Highgarden, Oldtown, the Arbor, Horn Hill, Ashford, Storm’s End, and Evenfall Hall had the honor of hosting His Grace many times, but Aegon could and would turn up almost anywhere, sometimes with as many as a thousand knights and lords and ladies in his train. He journeyed thrice to the Iron Islands (twice to Pyke and once to Great Wyk), spent a fortnight at Sisterton in 19 AC, and visited the North six times, holding court thrice in White Harbor, twice at Barrowton, and once at Winterfell on his very last royal progress in 33 AC.
verbs: taking his court from one castle to another
guesting with each of his great lords in turn.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon devoted his reign to an endless royal progress, taking his court from one castle to another and guesting with each of his great lords in turn. His first stop was Gulltown, where he had the support of Lord Orys Baratheon, who was Good Queen Alysanne's designated heir when her eldest brother died. From there soon followed visits to The Eyrie, Harrenhal and Riverrun before ending at Lannisport. Meanwhile visits were also made to Casterly Rock and Crakehall as well as Old Oak and Highgarden. When even more time was spent at Oldtown than anywhere else except King's Landing it seemed like all Aegon's love lay here in this ancient historical city surrounded by salt flats and smoky brimstone!
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon, devoted to taking his court from one castle to another in an endless royal progress, moved from King's Landing and Aegonfort to Gulltown, The Eyrie, Harrenhal and Riverrun. He visited the great western strongholds of Lannisport and Casterly Rock before arriving at Crakehall and Old Oak. Upon reaching Highgarden which had ten times more comfortable accommodation than the smoky Dragonstone where he had once spent his childhood - Aegon found himself even more devoted to its wonders! Here, he was safe under historical walls dining on salt fish and smokey bacon while His lords embraced him with love like a true king. Aegon felt he so belonged here as successive months were spent visiting different castles every month that took him to far ends of realm such as Evenfall Hall at Pyke or Great Wyk among many other places invited by some noble or the other; showing off both their power but also kindness through an everlasting hospitality that kept Aegon staying for weeks on end before moving on to the next castle or home.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: “It is better to forestall rebellions than to put them down,” Aegon famously said, when asked the reason for his journeys. A glimpse of the king in all his power, mounted on Balerion the Black Dread and attended by hundreds of knights glittering in silk and steel, did much to instill loyalty in restless lords. The smallfolk needed to see their kings and queens from time to time as well, the king added, and know that they might have the chance to lay their grievances and concerns before him.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon's glittering court, attended by devoted knights in silk and steel, traveled from Gulltown to The Eyrie all the way to Harrenhal and Riverrun then, Lannisport and Casterly Rock before continuing to Crakehall and Old Oak arriving at Highgarden. Everywhere he went his people were instilling with power; Aegon wanted none of the rebellions that had put many of his predecessors on the Iron Throne. During this endless royal progress he was determined to forestall any further disturbance by visiting even the far ends of The Realm and taking court in every castle his great lords owned. Thus, Smallfolk across Westeros saw their beloved king as he journeyed across seven kingdoms one after another making sure folks understood that no matter how far they lived they still held a place in Aegon's loving heart.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon and his court continued to forestall rebellions across the Seven Kingdoms by mounted tours of endless royal progress, taking his court from one castle to another and guesting with each of his great lords in turn. His glittering procession was attended by knights clothed in fine silk and steel and the smallfolk instilled him with a power that he needed. Some nights they encamped in Lord Edmyn Tully's Far Oak, some nights at Viserys Targaryen's old Dragonmont or on Addison Hill atop Harrenhal - but Aegon never stayed anywhere long enough to tire of it.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: And so they did. Much of every royal progress was given over to feasts and balls and hunts and hawking, as every lord attempted to outdo the others in splendor and hospitality, but Aegon also made a point of holding court wherever he might travel, whether from a dais in some great lord’s castle or a mossy stone in a farmer’s field. Six maesters traveled with him, to answer any questions he might have on local law, customs, and history, and to make note of such decrees and judgments as His Grace might hand down. A lord should know the land he rules, the Conqueror later told his son Aenys, and through his travels Aegon learned much and more about the Seven Kingdoms and its peoples.
events: feasts and balls and hunts and hawking
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: King Aegon and his brother, Aenys, traveled across the seven kingdoms in a royal progress of feasts and balls and hunts and hawking. Everywhere they went, the people gathered to behold the great splendor of their royal visitors, gracing them with generous hospitality. The smallfolk put on glittering show for their illustrious guests while knights attired in vibrant silks and steel attended them wherever they went. Though he never expected rebellion to appear on this solemn journey, Aegon still instilled it into all who saw him: he needed them to understand who held the power here. His presence was enough to forestall any attempted dissent as they made their way from castle to farmer's field; each new place learning just how much greatness could be contained within two Targaryen brothers
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon and Aenys accompanied by knights, glittering in silk and steel put their plan into action; the royal progress was a means to regain control and power of the kingdom. From castle to farmer's field, they traveled, feasting and hunting along the way. In each lord's court where they stopped on their journey, Aegon and Aenys sought to instill order while offering great splendor and hospitality as reward for loyalty. They made note of all they had learned from the smallfolk during their travels in hopes it would prove needed when confronting rebellions that might forestall them from reaching an ultimate goal - unifying all seven kingdoms one.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Each of the conquered kingdoms had its own laws and traditions. King Aegon did little to interfere with those. He allowed his lords to continue to rule much as they always had, with all the same powers and prerogatives. The laws of inheritance and succession remained unchanged, the existing feudal structures were confirmed, lords both great and small retained the power of pit and gallows on their own land, and the privilege of the first night wherever that custom had formerly prevailed.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: King Aegon had conquered and allowed many kingdoms to continue their existing laws, both great and small. He confirmed the rights of many of the prior lords and kings, retained or acquired new castles, and was ever generous towards those who bent the knee. On his royal progress he traveled far and wide, holding court in rather humble dwellings such as a farmer's field instead of sumptuous palaces - where he made note of their hospitality amid the splendor. Even a mere man who beheld King Aegon was impressed by his great power and kindness that allowed so much to remain unchanged despite having been conquered.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: King Aegon had conquered all seven kingdoms, but he allowed the existing laws and customs to remain in place, confirming and retaining that which the Seven Kingdoms already possessed. His royal progress was a testament to his great splendor; feasts, balls and hunts, hawking-- these were all held at every corner of his realm; both small castles and vast holdfasts were endowed with great hospitality as they traveled and held court. Everywhere Aegon went on this grand tour, he made note of what he learned at each stop: how things were done across Westeros-- from Highgarden in the Reach to Dragonstone near Dorne-- allowing them to continue their own traditions without interference.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Aegon’s chief concern was peace. Before the Conquest, wars between the realms of Westeros were common. Hardly a year passed without someone fighting someone somewhere. Even in those kingdoms said to be at peace, neighboring lords oft settled their disputes at swordpoint. Aegon’s accession put an end to much of that. Petty lords and landed knights were now expected to take their disputes to their liege lords and abide by their judgments. Arguments between the great houses of the realm were adjudicated by the Crown. “The first law of the land shall be the King’s Peace,” King Aegon decreed, “and any lord who goes to war without my leave shall be considered a rebel and an enemy of the Iron Throne.”
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: King Aegon had successfully conquered Westeros through the Conquest and established his rule across seven kingdoms one. As expected, he then set about fighting to settle existing rivalries between places like Evenfall Hall and Tarth, adjudicating new disputes between the bastion born King Jaehaerys the Conciliator and a Redwyne girl from Gulltown. With decrees from Harrenhal down to Sisterton, he allowed small lords great leeway in their local affairs, confirming their rights that had been retained even before Aegon's grand victory. He goes as far as allowing each chief local lord over petty matters such as common justice within their lands, but ultimately sovereign authority was vested in him alone.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: King Aegon had conquered Westeros during his Conquest, but it was expected that he would adjudicate and decree who will hold what lands from the great to the petty. And so it goes that Aegon settled on making his eldest son Loren Lannister's heir of Casterly Rock and suppporting him as chief among common lords in the seven kingdoms one, while confirming the existing great lords to remain in place and retain their power over small lords. This way, stability throughout the realm was maintained and fighting avoided amongst old enemies. Meanwhile, countries around Westeros recognized this decision as fact with Evenstar of Tarth, King Jaehaerys even allowing House Blackwood and house Harlaw to remain separate yet equal partners in rule with every corner of the realm adjudicated well by Aegon's wise hand.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: King Aegon also issued decrees regularizing customs, duties, and taxes throughout the realm, whereas previously every port and every petty lord had been free to exact however much they could from tenants, smallfolk, and merchants. He also proclaimed that the holy men and women of the Faith, and all their lands and possessions, were to be exempt from taxation, and affirmed the right of the Faith’s own courts to try and sentence any septon, Sworn Brother, or holy sister accused of malfeasance. Though not himself a godly man, the first Targaryen king always took care to court the support of the Faith and the High Septon of Oldtown.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: When King Aegon the Dragon proclaimed Westeros to be his own, he began to take steps to regularizing the exact borders which he and his descendants would rule over. He affirmed this in a court held at Visenya's Hill, anointed by holy septons and godly maesters alike, with all of the major lords and banners of Westeros present. With them he decreed that every corner of the realm was now under Targaryen rule; from Evenfall Hall in the far ends of the realm, to Tarth on one end, Gulltown on another, down towards Storm's End and up past The Eyrie until Seven Kingdoms were ruled as one.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: King Aegon was determined to regularizing his kingship in the Seven Kingdoms and so he proclaimed the exact precise manner in which justice was to be affirmed by the court, claiming that it would be holy, godly even. In his doing so he settled a dispute among Aegonfort, Highgarden and Maidenpool to which many houses had expected him to adjudicate or decree - a common occurrence as every petty lord across Westeros looks to their King as their chief authority figure.Lord Edmyn Tully had presented himself at court with his long held grievance of House Harlaw over an old wrong; a crime that likely goes back past Aenys Targaryen who conquered this land in earlier days. Fortunately for Lord Tully, King Aegon decided on behalf of House Harlaw and goes down as another example of how assertive yet fair Aegon The Conqueror truly is -- garnering admiration from evens the most great of houses throughout all corners of Westeros.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: King’s Landing grew up around Aegon and his court, on and about the three great hills that stood near the mouth of the Blackwater Rush. The highest of those hills had become known as Aegon’s High Hill, and soon enough the lesser hills were being called Visenya’s Hill and the Hill of Rhaenys, their former names forgotten. The crude motte-and- bailey fort that Aegon had thrown up so quickly was neither large enough nor grand enough to house the king and his court, and had begun to expand even before the Conquest was complete. A new keep was erected, all of logs and fifty feet high, with a cavernous longhall beneath it, and a kitchen, made of stone and roofed with slate in case of fire, across the bailey. Stables appeared, then a granary. A new watchtower was raised, twice as tall as the older one. Soon the Aegonfort was threatening to burst out of its walls, so a new palisade was raised, enclosing more of the hilltop, creating space enough for a barracks, an armory, a sept, and a drum tower.
adjectives: great hills near mouth Blackwater Rush
roofed with slate in case of fire
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: King Aegon had proclaimed his conquest of the Seven Kingdoms, and after that it seemed as though the great hills near the mouth of Blackwater Rush grew overnight. A crude motte-and-bailey fort, fifty feet high and with a cavernous longhall beneath it, was erected on Aegon's High Hill and another appeared on Visenya's Hill while an enormous wooden keep burst out of its walls on Rhaenys's Hill. From these glorious foundations there blossomed a great city which soon surrounded them: King’s Landing. It was here that Good Queen Alysanne affirmed court justice and reinforced her husband’s holy godly rule in the seven kingdoms one; she even visited every corner of the realm to encourage regularizing customs across Westeros.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: King Aegon had proclaimed regularizing his reign throughout the court and affirmed himself as holy and godly. When he grew older, along with his sister-wives Visenya and Rhaenys, the Three of them began their Conquest forming King's Landing at what is now known to be Aegon's High Hill. While Visenya threw up her own castle on an hill that later came to be known as Visenya's Hill, Rhaenys too builded a great fortress upon adjacent hill - Hill of Rhaenys. The newly constructed city soon appeared among the crude motte-and-bailey fort thrown up fifty feet high by Aegon near the mouth of Blackwater Rush together with its great hills near it; under which dwelled in its cavernous longhall roofed with slate in case of fire. Amongst this regal setting emerged Loren Lannister’s eldest son, fulfilling his destiny as heir to Evenstar of Tarth thus completing Jaehaarlys’s task undertaken in Conclave far beyond Winterfell years ago.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Below the hills, wharves and storehouses were rising along the riverbanks, and merchants from Oldtown and the Free Cities were tying up beside the longships of the Velaryons and Celtigars, where only a few fishing boats had previously been seen. Much of the trade that had gone through Maidenpool and Duskendale was now coming to King’s Landing. A fish market sprung up along the riverside, a cloth market between the hills. A customs house appeared. A modest sept opened on the Blackwater, in the hull of an old cog, followed by a stouter one of daub-and-wattle on the shore. Then a second sept, twice as large and thrice as grand, was built atop Visenya’s Hill, with coin sent by the High Septon. Shops and homes sprouted like mushrooms after a rain. Wealthy men raised walled manses on the hillsides, whilst the poor gathered in squalid hovels of mud and straw in the low places between.
events: a fish market sprung up along the riverside, a cloth market between the hills.
A modest sept opened on the Blackwater.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: The newly built motte-and-bailey fort, on the great hill near the mouth of Blackwater Rush, fifty feet high and an underground cavernous longhall beneath it roofed with slate in case of fire, had drawn people from far ends of the realm. Wealthy merchants tied up their ships along the riverside and springing up between Aegon's High Hill and Visenya's Hill was a modest market for cloth. Between Hills of Rhaenys and Visenya, a fish market sprung up along the riverside, with those gathered around being both wealthy or poor. Squalid who would normally remain hidden on even further crevices of Westeros were seen standing around Duskendale occasionally. The customs house appeared at King’s Landing as if it had burst out of its walls itself and a sept opened near Maidenpool commemorating Good Queen Alysanne where Richard Roote was appointed as High Septon.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: In the fifty years since Aegon, Visenya and Rhaenys conquered King’s Landing, a flourishing ty-town had sprung up around it. Oldtown and the Free Cities sent immigrants to open shops in Maidenpool and Duskendale; merchants gathered between Visenya's Hill and the Hill of Rhaenys; a fish market sprang up along the riverside, a cloth market between the hills. A customs house was built on Visenya's Hill near Aegonfort, where wealthy families from around Westeros now lived in comfort while all around them squalid tents were erected as poor immigrants crowded into King's Landing looking for work. The city walls were raised higher too, enclosing all these new people within, then Lord Alton Celtigar all but closed off Blackwater Rush with a wall of his own--but none could stop its prosperity: soon buildings burst out of its walls creating great hills near mouth Blackwater Rush many times more grand than that once crude motte-and-bailey fort fifty feet high with nothing but a cavernous longhall beneath it roofed with slate in case of fire.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: No one planned King’s Landing. It simply grew…but it grew quickly. At Aegon’s first coronation, it was still a village squatting beneath a motte-and-bailey castle. By his second, it was already a thriving town of several thousand souls. By 10 AC, it was a true city, almost as large as Gulltown or White Harbor. By 25 AC, it had outgrown both to become the third most populous city in the realm, surpassed only by Lannisport and Oldtown.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon's coronation was a grand affair, planned with as much care as Aegon had devoted to establishing his kingdom. He chose "King's Landing" for its symbolic value, only heightening the event's importance throughout Westeros and the Free Cities. The castles of Lannisport, Gulltown, White Harbor and Oldtown were all built upon his order by lords pledging allegiance to him; their efforts paid off when thousands gathered in King's Landing on the coronation day, many braving distances across land and sea to witness this momentous occasion. The city not only grew larger but more prosperous as well; gone were the squalid warehouses and small residences that had previously lined its streets - instead they were filled with wealthy merchants, vibrant markets and even bustling ports such as Maidenpool. At sunset over Dragonmont hill, Aegon shared his hopes for a true golden age – an era of peace where no one’s loyalty would be divided and everyone could reap the rewards of this thriving Kingdom.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon's coronation as the King of the Seven Kingdoms was planned meticulously to bring prosperity and peace. He had grown outgrown his father's rule, and now he strove to make King's Landing a thriving hub of culture and life. In order to do so, Aenys' Targaryen and Leo Lannister's eldest son joined forces in building fortifications all around Gulltown and White Harbor, while they raised walls in Oldtown which would soon be an inviting gathering place for both the wealthy and poor alike. In this way, Aegon turned what was once fragmented cities into true powerhouses that were able to weather any storms - both metaphorical ones from within the kingdoms, or literal ones like those thrown at them by Dornish cutthroats from beyond Westeros' far reaches.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Unlike its rivals, however, King’s Landing had no walls. It needed none, some of its residents were known to say; no enemy would ever dare attack the city so long as it was defended by the Targaryens and their dragons. The king himself might have shared these views originally, but the death of his sister Rhaenys and her dragon, Meraxes, in 10 AC and the attacks upon his own person undoubtedly gave him cause And in the 19th year After the Conquest, word reached Westeros of a daring raid in the Summer Isles, where a pirate fleet had sacked Tall Trees Town and carried off a thousand women and children as slaves, along with a fortune in plunder. The accounts of the raid greatly troubled the king, who realized that King’s Landing would be similarly vulnerable to any enemy shrewd enough to fall upon the city when he and Visenya were elsewhere. Accordingly, His Grace ordered the construction of a ring of walls about King’s Landing, as high and strong as those that protected Oldtown and Lannisport. The task of building them was conferred upon Grand Maester Gawen and Ser Osmund Strong, the Hand of the King. To honor the Seven, Aegon decreed that the city would have seven gates, each defended by a massive gatehouse and defensive towers. Work on the walls began the next year and continued until 26 AC.
verbs: ordered the construction of a ring of walls,
defended by a massive gatehouse and defensive towers.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon, Rhaenys and Meraxes led a raid in the Summer Isles, they traveled thousands of miles to reach it. As the legend would say, they gave the Summer Islanders a chance to yield and submit before leading their men into battle. The Targaryens held true to this tradition, but after meeting much resistance they sieged the island with fire and sword. They sacked the villages ruthlessly and carried off much plunder for their efforts. Aegon felt that a ring of walls were needed to better defend these islands from future threats so he ordered their construction along with a massive gatehouse and defensive towers. Such was his will that Westeros itself soon followed suit as every corner of the realm worked on building its own defenses.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon, together with his sister Rhaenys and dragon Meraxes, planned a raid in the Summer Isles, reaching as far as the Tall Trees Town. He gave orders to sack and plunder the town, thus carrying off much of its wealth to Westeros. He also ordered the construction of a ring of walls around King’s Landing that were defended by a massive gatehouse and defensive towers. The mouth of Blackwater Bay had grown so full and outgrown Gulltown and White Harbor that it was now a thriving port in its own right. Aegon I had become a true conqueror after this successful campaign - something even his father Jaehaerys would say boasted great glory.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Ser Osmund was the king’s fourth Hand. His first had been Lord Orys Baratheon, his bastard half-brother and companion of his youth, but Lord Orys was taken captive during the Dornish War and suffered the loss of his sword hand. When ransomed back, his lordship asked the king to be relieved of his duties. “The King’s Hand should have a hand,” he said. “I will not have men speaking of the King’s Stump.” Aegon next called on Edmyn Tully, Lord of Riverrun, to take up the Handship. Lord Edmyn served from 7–9 AC, but when his wife died in childbed, he decided that his children had more need of him than the realm, and begged leave to return to the riverlands. Alton Celtigar, Lord of Claw Isle, replaced Tully, serving ably as Hand until his death from natural causes in 17 AC, after which the king named Ser Osmund Strong.
events: the Kings Hand should have a hand
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Ser Osmund had just returned from the Dornish War, where he had suffered a great loss of his sword hand. When Aegon heard about it, he was relieved and said that a King's Hand should have a hand, so he immediately named Lord Orys Baratheon as his fourth Hand. Aegon also called upon Lord Edmyn Tully to join the authority and before long Alton Celtigar was made part of it too, who at the time happened to be Roberts bastard half-brother. They reigned in these positions until they were replaced by Aegon I Targaryen’s son Aenys and his successors when they reached Westeros after sacking Tall Trees Town while raiding in the Summer Isles.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Ser Osmund, Lord Orys Baratheon and Lord Edmyn Tully returned from the Dornish War triumphant but with a profound loss as Ser Osmund lost his sword hand. Alton Celtigar, King Jaehaerys' bastard half-brother was named as the fourth Hand of the King's after it was decided that the Kings Hand should have a hand - first by natural causes then again due to Ser Osmund's injury. To defend their success in battle Grande Maester Lyonce joined Loren Lannister’s eldest son and Aegon Targaryen, Evenstar of Tarth at Maidenpool to discuss building a ring of walls around Westeros. The trio soon sallied forth talking along Tall Trees Town’s side roads discussing how they would carry out such an enormous feat. But neither were prepared for what awaited them when ventured into Oldtown - raids had plundered supplies leaving the once strong city vulnerable and fragile in its wake. Yet, with the help of House Blackwood and smallfolk near Gulltown they were able to construct defensive towers which guarded King's Landing grandly.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Grand Maester Gawen was the third in that office. Aegon Targaryen had always kept a maester on Dragonstone, as his father and father’s father had before him. All the great lords of Westeros, and many lesser lords and landed knights, relied upon maesters trained in the Citadel of Oldtown to serve their households as healers, scribes, and counselors, to breed and train the ravens who carried their messages (and write and read those messages for lords who lacked those skills), help their stewards with the household accounts, and teach their children. During the Conquest, Aegon and his sisters each had a maester serving them, and afterward the king sometimes employed as many as half a dozen to deal with all the matters brought before him.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Grand Maester Gawen was present at the time of Aegon Targaryen's Conquest and kept track of all that had transpired, along with an army of lesser maesters to breed and train dragons and carry out his orders. As the Conqueror relied upon him to keep accurate records, not only did he write faithfully but also read greedily from every corner of the realm – unearthing tales long lost in evenfall halls or buried under farmer's field in distant lands. His great study now housed scrolls from Oldtown, The Eyrie, Dragonstone or Tarth - it echoed with stories of Viserys' greatness that Grand Maester Gawen strove hard to employ for his own brilliance. He remembered how House Corbray welcomed her sixteen Targaryens; how Lord Orys Baratheon first named Jon Arryn as fourth Hand; Good Queen Alysanne's crowning marriage with house Blackwood; Sixteen year old Torrhen Stark bowing before Aegon I; lords who stepped forth when King Jaehaerys could not settle Dornish War at Riverrun; Lord Edmyn Tully standing tall for loss of his sword hand and Alton Celtigar welcoming bastard half-brother as Robert returned relieved by news sent by Starry Sept declaring that Kings Hand should have a hand after all! Grand Maester Gawen relished these moments and more as he prepared himself to report on what would happen next to Aegon Targaryen at Dragonstone.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Grand Maester Gawen had been at Dragonstone since the days of Aegon Targaryen's Conquest, having come from Oldtown to serve as a trusted advisor. Through him and seven generations of maesters that followed, Aegon and his heirs learned how to keep culture alive through written records, inspired works of literature, reliance upon magic and the rare breed of dragons kept under their control. From Grand Maester Gawen onward great knowledge was maintained by the realm's elite on matters ranging from understanding politics abroad to training horses for jousting tournaments--even in far ends of the realm like Iron Throne or Hill of Rhaenys.  It seemed no matter what corner Aegon looked too he could always rely upon the faithfulness of his maesters even in trying times such as those brought about by Dornish War with Lord Orys Baratheon's return marked with pronounced loss of his sword hand. Though tidings were dealt thankfully relieved it was decreed that The King Hand should have a hand still capable enough to draw a blade in defense; thus King Jaehaerys named his bastard half-brother Ser Osmund fourth The King Hand following old Lord Edmyn Tully and Alton Celtigar before him.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: But the wisest and most learned men in the Seven Kingdoms were the archmaesters of the Citadel, each of them the supreme authority in one of the great disciplines. In 5 AC, King Aegon, feeling that the realm might benefit from such wisdom, asked the Conclave to send him one of their own number to advise and consult with him on all matters relating to the governance of the realm. Thus was the office of Grand Maester created, at King Aegon’s request.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon asked the Conclave of Maesters, assembled at the Citadel in Oldtown, to create what they believed was wisest and most learned man in all Seven Kingdoms. After much discussion and contemplation, Grand Maester Gawen emerged as their selection; a talented maester brought up from Dragonstone who had relied upon his knowledge and skills to help Aegon conquer and unify the land. The Grand Maester has continued since then to keep control over the landed lordships of Westeros through wise policies that rely upon supporting great houses with lesser ones, training competent men for services like writing and reading, or employing cunning strategies such as embroiling oneself in Dornish war-games. All this was done to ensure Aegon's realm remained strong throughout the far ends of the realm.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon and the Conclave of Archmaesters, whom Grand Maester Gawen had asked to create a great council of the wisest and most learned minds in Westeros, were gathered together at the Citadel in Oldtown. The Seven Kingdoms waited with anticipation for what this ancient seat of learning would decree, as lords both great and lesser looked to them for guidance and relied upon their words on matters both within the land and beyond its borders.  Aegon had journeyed from Dragonstone where he had conquered seven kingdoms one by one, accompanied by his sister-queens Rhaenys and Visenya as they bred, trained and carried dragons far into every corner of the realm. He trusted that here at Oldtown, now amongst these "masters of coin", a powerful new force could coalesce that would write history anew.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The first man to serve in that capacity was Archmaester Ollidar, keeper of histories, whose ring and rod and mask were bronze. Though exceptionally learned, Ollidar was also exceptionally old, and he passed from this world less than a year after taking up the mantle of Grand Maester. To fill his place, the Conclave selected Archmaester Lyonce, whose ring and rod and mask were yellow gold. He proved more robust than his predecessor, serving the realm until 12 AC, when he slipped in the mud, broke his hip, and died soon thereafter, whereupon Grand Maester Gawen was elevated.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Archmaester Ollidar, Archmaester Lyonce and Grand Maester Gawen each had served the new King with exceptionaly excellence and so were selected to serve as Grand Maesters of the Seven Kingdoms. But, on their way from Casterly Rock to Citadel, misfortune stuck them after Gawen slipped in the mud and broken his leg. No one expected things to take a turn for worse until a distant cousin of Aegon the Dragon arrived at Evenfall Hall from Tarth claiming he should be the next ruler of Seven Kingdoms. Conclave was asked to create a team of wisest and most robust old maesters who could challenge this powerful challenger and restablish order in Westeros.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Archmaester Lyonce's idea of the Conclave seemed even more absurd when Grand Maester Gawen slipped in the mud trying to serve as their elected leader. Aegon had been asked to create the wisest and most learned group of men, yet three of those selected were elevated exceptationally quickly - Archmaester Ollidar, a tall septon; Alton Celtigar, an old hedge knight bastard born; and Richard Roote from House Harlaw. All three proved to be both wise and robust beyond expectation, helping lay the foundations for what would become some of the strongest rulers in seven kingdoms history - King Jaehaerys, Queen Alysanne, King Robert and all Sixteen Targaryens that followed.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The institution of the king’s small council did not come into its full bloom until the reign of King Jaehaerys the Conciliator, but that is not to suggest that Aegon I ruled without the benefit of counsel. He is known to have consulted often with his various Grand Maesters, and his own household maesters as well. On matters relating to taxation, debts, and incomes, he sought the advice of his masters of coin. Though he kept one septon at King’s Landing and another at Dragonstone, the king more oft wrote to the High Septon of Oldtown on religious issues, and always made a point of visiting the Starry Sept during his yearly circuit. More than any of these, King Aegon relied upon the King’s Hand, and of course upon his sisters, the Queens Rhaenys and Visenya.
events: institution of the king’s small council
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: King Jaehaerys the Conciliator, a great and wise king, had consulted with Aegon I Targaryen after his conquering of the seven kingdoms. With input from the Grand Maesters, masters of coin and High Septon of Oldtown from Starry Sept, he instutioned the King’s Small Council to be his most trusted advisors. After touring through hallowed places such as King's Landing and Dragonstone, The Conciliator had also visited diverse territories like Oldtown in full bloom where he sought advice yearly. He was joined by Queens Rhaenys and Visenya on his visiting endeavor while seeking counsel from lords such as Lord Monkeyface and Evenstar of Tarth who gave opinions that aided in decisions often made in court by their wiser than thought grandfather.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: King Jaehaerys the Conciliator had consulted Grand Maesters, masters of coin, High Septon of Oldtown and even sought advice from his two Queens Rhaenys and Visenya before he institutioned his small council in King's Landing. The Starry Sept was visited in full bloom every year by the Kings Hand while Aegon I Targaryen made tour of Dragonsone and Oldtown to discuss the matters with advisers. Evenstar of Tarth attended some meetings as a guest along with her brothers and tall septons. The concilors carefully selected Lord Orys Baratheon for council after observing his robust knowledge about war (refers to previous_paragraph). It was said that Queen Visenyas speeches could make even Lord Monkeyface shed tears - truly an exceptionaly old phenomenon! Gregor Goode and Dornish cutthroat joined ranks one after another as sworn swords of House Blackwood at same instance making them eligible for Council’s selection to serve Kingdom’s needs.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Rhaenys was a great patron to the bards and singers of the Seven Kingdoms, showering gold and gifts on those who pleased her. Though Queen Visenya thought her sister frivolous, there was a wisdom in this that went beyond a simple love of music. For the singers of the realm, in their eagerness to win the favor of the queen, composed many a song in praise of House Targaryen and King Aegon, and then went forth and sang those songs in every keep and castle and village green from the Dornish Marches to the Wall. Thus was the Conquest made glorious to the simple people, whilst Aegon the Dragon himself became a hero king.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaenys and Queen Visenya, having accompanied King Aegon on his glorious Conquests across the Seven Kingdoms, had proposed far-reaching reforms along the way. During their travels through Dornish Marches to the Wall and on to Summer Isles; they showered love, good will and bestowed grace upon each of the kingdoms they visited. It was even said that Queen Rhaenys composed small songs in celebration of her journey while Queen Visenya sang frivolously in praise of her brother's Conquest. Their footprints became legendary in every corner of the realm as they spread peace and prosperity like an Evergreen tree attaining full bloom during its' yearly cycle.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Queen Rhaenys, Queen Visenya and King Aegon left the crumbling ruins of Dragonmont in the Seven Kingdoms to begin their Conquest. Showering cries of delight from their followers, they rode through Dornish Marches, Oldtown and even as far North as The Wall with a spirit like no other. Composed songs were sang by bards as they reminded everyone that "the gods had become one" after a year full of frivolous battles such as the War at Maidenpool and Gulltown. This was indeed glorious! As Richard Roote, an old hedge knight said - "This young Targaryen king will be remembered forever!", while Evenstar of Tarth shouted," Long live King Aegon!".

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Rhaenys also took a great interest in the smallfolk, and had a special love for women and children. Once, when she was holding court in the Aegonfort, a man was brought before her for beating his wife to death. The woman’s brothers wanted him punished, but the husband argued that he was within his lawful rights, since he had found his wife abed with another man. The right of a husband to chastise an erring wife was well established throughout the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne). The husband further pointed out that the rod he had used to beat his wife was no thicker than his thumb, and even produced the rod in evidence. When the queen asked him how many times he had struck his wife, however, the husband could not answer, but the dead woman’s brothers insisted there had been a hundred blows.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaenys was hailed as the 'The Queen Who Bore The Torch', due to her obsession with justice. Every day at the Aegonfort, she held court ensuring the smallfolk of seven kingdoms (save in Dorne) were getting their lawful rights. Her brothers and a select few others sat alongside her on the judgement seat, striking down those who did not comply with her rulings. When Queen Rhaenys saw a man and woman from Evenfall Hall arguing fiercely in front of her, she quickly chastised them for their frivolous behavior before producing an even tone that sang through her words. This charisma and special love earned from the Seven Kingdoms soon became glorious talk across borders all the way to far ends of Westeros, including The Free Cities and beyond.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Queen Rhaenys wasted no time in holding court, wherever the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne) lay; from Aegonfort to Tall Trees Town. The smallfolk saw only kindness and special love from her, and every lawful right was given out, so it is not surprising that she soon gained renown all across Westeros. On one such visit to a farmer's field on the Dornish Marches came an incident where Queen Rhaenys had to chastise a man and woman who quarrelled with her brothers claiming they had wronged them. After striking both of them one by one with her showel, Queen Rhaenys sternly produced parchments detailing their rights - something she became renowned for. Despite the gravity of this situation, empathy shone on the two offenders inspiring what could be seen as frivolous adoration for the glorious queen.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Rhaenys consulted with her maesters and septons, then rendered her decision. An adulterous wife gave offense to the Seven, who had created women to be faithful and obedient to their husbands, and therefore must be chastised. As god has but seven faces, however, the punishment should consist of only six blows (for the seventh blow would be for the Stranger, and the Stranger is the face of death). Thus the first six blows the man had struck had been lawfu but the remaining ninety-four had been an offense against gods and men, and must be punished in kind. From that day forth, the “rule of six” became a part of the common law, along with the “rule of thumb.” (The husband was taken to the foot of the Hill of Rhaenys, where he was given ninety-four blows by the dead woman’s brothers, using rods of lawful size.)
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaenys looked out over the Hill of Rhaenys, her gaze taking in the lush green fields and farms which surrounded it. Her gaze settled upon a small group of maesters and septons who had been summoned with consultation. The Queen listened to their wise counsel as they rendered justice upon those whom had broken the law; she chastised those for their transgressions yet taken pity when circumstances called for it, giving mercy where it was earned by the adulterous or faithful; finally she gave Lordship and Lawful rights to any who had proven themselves obedient subjects of hers. Soon, what news on this Hill reached every corner of the Seven Kingdoms; farmers from near and far lands knew that justice would be served from atop this mountaintop.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Queen Rhaenys and her brothers, Aenys and Torrhen Stark, carefully consulted the maesters and septons when holding court on the Hill of Rhaenys. They took counsel from both men of faith and men of letters regarding how to render judgement, and how to chastise those who had transgressed lawful rights. Queen Rhaenys was particularly strict with any who were adulterous or unfaithful - swift justice was taken as soon as it was given by Queen Rhaenys upon all those disobedient to law. She also held a special love for her smallfolk, whose rights she sought to uphold no matter what corner of the Seven Kingdoms (save in Dorne) they resided in.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Queen Visenya did not share her sister’s love of music and song. She was not without humor, however, and for many years kept her own fool, a hirsute hunchback called Lord Monkeyface whose antics amused her greatly. When he choked to death on a peach pit, the queen acquired an ape and dressed it in Lord Monkeyface’s clothing. “The new one is cleverer,” she was wont to say.
events: choked to death on a peach pit
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Queen Visenya kept her own fool and was known to frequently indulge in the ridicule of less fortunate people. At a feast, Visenya choked to death on a peach pit; however, she left behind one memorable figure in court - Lord Monkeyface. A hirsute creature of little fortune and even smaller brains, Queen Visenya dressed Lord Monkeyface up in all sorts of fantastical clothing befitting his unusualness - stories say she even acquired an ape for him once! The Queen shared an odd love for the fool that amused everyone from the maesters at Evenfall Hall to those septons who visited her at Visenya's Hill. Undoubtedly cleverer than his physical form would suggest, Lord Monkeyface has become an everlasting symbol throughout Westeros; especially during House Targaryen’s reign when many maids swooned over his hunchback charm as much were as they did with Aegon the Dragon himself!
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Queen Visenya Targaryen had a fittingly tempestuous relationship with her brother, Lord Monkeyface. They would often share love and jolly hours at Viseyna's Hill, the place where Visenya kept her own fool, choked to death on a peach pit, and famously acquired an ape she dressed in silk and amused herself immensely with it's hirsute hunchbacked cleverness. Queen Visenya was known throughout Westeros as one of the 16 Targaryens that also included Lake Lannister's eldest son, Evenstar of Tarth, King Jaehaerys and Gregor Goode that intitled her to share in Aegon I's power across all seven Kingdoms (save Dorne). In stark contrast to her sister Rhaenys who consulted Maesters and septons from The Highgarden Maidenpool Iron Throne Dragonstone Crakehall Winterfell Hill of Rhaenys until everybody including the Kingsguard House Blackwood  was taken aback by her rending judgement for adulterous faithless obedient or lawful deeds; when it came to ruling Queens Rhaenys raised all low while Viseny my gave Thrones away.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Yet there was darkness in Visenya Targaryen. To most of the world, she presented the grim face of a warrior, stern and unforgiving. Even her beauty had an edge to it, her admirers said. The oldest of the three heads of the dragon, Visenya was to outlive both of her siblings, and it was rumored that in her later years, when she could no longer wield a sword, she delved into the dark arts, mixing poisons and casting malign spells. Some even suggest that she might have been a kinslayer and a kingslayer, though no proof has ever been offered to support such calumnies.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Visenya Targaryen was a woman that demanded respect - her steady gaze, stern attitude and forthright manner only made it easier for people to understand just how much power she could wield. She delved deep into magic and the arcane arts, mixing spells and potions together with a mix of grim determination and unforgiving beauty. People whispered across far ends of the realm about all that Visenya was capable of, but none knew what secrets she kept hidden. While Queen Visenya had thrilled many in her lifetime with her hirsute ape companion Lord Monkeyface - who kept his own fool before he choked to death on a peach pit - as well as dressing him up in fine cloths during amusements at Evenfall Hall - there were also fewer who understood how clever or calculated this Targaryen sister could be.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Queen Visenya had always been known for her strength and fierce will, which was evident to all when Lord Monkeyface once said that she kept her own fool better than any other royal. Her reputation only grew after the surprising news of his terrible death; he had choked to death on a peach pit, quite unbecoming for someone as proud of themselves as him. Some attributed it to divine justice for having acquired an ape without consulting the Gods. Despite come speculation, there were few who truly understood what made Visenya Targaryen so feared and respected by many in the Seven Kingdoms - her adeptness at wielding Divine magic. She had delved deep into its dark corners, much like she did with mixing ordinary with magical ingredients while casting spells; a grim yet unforgiving beauty that revealed why so many feared and admired Queen Visenya's stern gaze throughout Westeros.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: It would be a cruel irony if true, for in her youth no one did more to protect the king. Visenya twice wielded Dark Sister in Aegon’s defense when he was set upon by Dornish cutthroats. Suspicious and ferocious by turns, she trusted no one but her brother. During the Dornish War, she took to wearing a shirt of mail night and day, even under her court clothes, and urged the king to do the same. When Aegon refused, Visenya grew furious. “Even with Blackfyre in your hand, you are only one man,” she told him, “and I cannot always be with you.” When the king pointed out that he had guardsmen around him, Visenya drew Dark Sister and slashed him across the cheek so quickly the guards had no time to react. “Your guards are slow and lazy,” she said. “I could have killed you as easily as I cut you. You require better protection.” King Aegon, bleeding, had no choice but to agree.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Visenya Targaryen was in the midst of the Dornish War, wielding her sword with grim and unforgiving beauty. Her youngest brother Aegon urged her to protect their king from a Dornish cutthroat but she refused, instead slashing towards the cruel and suspicious enemy. The ferocity with which Visenya wielded her sword had been honed during her journey across Westeros with Aegon as they delved into every corner of the realm, mixing magic and steel. No one told them they couldn't reforge the world—and that is exactly what they were trying to do.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Visenya Targaryen, who had wielded her mix of beauty and stern delicacy like a weapon throughout the Dornish war, urgently urged her brother Aegon to protect the king as they encountered a cruel, suspicious and ferocious Dornish cutthroat. While he refused at first; Visenya's uncompromising strength told him that she would not be swayed so easily. She rushed forward, sword drawn, slashing out with all the ferocity of a true Targaryen. Evenstar knew their cause was too important for anything less - she would see it through until either King Jaehaerys or her brothers were victorious in this unforgiving conflict.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Many kings had champions to defend them. Aegon was the Lord of the Seven Kingdoms; therefore, he should have seven champions, Queen Visenya decided. Thus did the Kingsguard come into being; a brotherhood of seven knights, the finest in the realm, cloaked and armored all in purest white, with no purpose but to defend the king, giving up their own lives for his if need be. Visenya modeled their vows on those of the Night’s Watch; like the black-cloaked crows of the Wall, the White Swords served for life, surrendering all their lands, titles, and worldly goods to live a life of chastity and obedience, with no reward but honor.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Aegon and Visenya rode together to the Seven Kingdoms, determined to form the Kingsguard to defend their people from ever surrendering again. The Kingsguard clad themselves in purest white, signifying their commitment to protectorate and honour, with oaths of chastity, obedience and service. Aegon's knights were only the finest of Westeros and were known for their ferocity just as much as their loyalty. When a Dornish cutthroat had surged forward towards him during the struggle of the Dornish War, Visenya urged him onward while Aegon refused - she slashed down with her blade twice before telling him that he should learn not be so suspicious if he hoped to live through such moments. All around them they could see evidence of his sister's kindness mixed amongst Grand Maester Gawen's Sixteen Targaryens - tales spread far and wide throughout all corners of the realm about even this small moment in time.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Aegon and Visenya had seen the horrors of Dornish War, and so when King Jaehaerys urged for the formation of a unit to protect the realm Aegon had no hesitation in surrendering his own life to be served. Eight knights chosen from all corners of Westeros stood tall in purest white robes, sworn to live lives of chastity, obedience and honor. Defending the king and six Seven Kingdoms was their singular cause, an event that would shape history forever as they had refused surrendering even when faced with his ferocity a cruel suspicious.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: So many knights came forward to offer themselves as candidates for the Kingsguard that King Aegon considered holding a great tourney to determine which of them was the most worthy. Visenya would not hear of it, however. To be a Kingsguard knight required more than just skill at arms, she pointed out. She would not risk placing men of uncertain loyalty about the king, regardless of how well they performed in a melee. She would choose the knights herself.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: King Aegon and Visenya came forward to the tourney as required, holding great risk in their hands as they did so. All around them brave warriors made ready for the melee, each exhibiting the same skillful and worthy qualities that would be needed to protect those who sought passage through Seven Kingdoms. From the finest knights of Kingsguard defending against a surrendering enemy to humbly serve their lords following purest white cloaks of chasitity, obedience, and honor - all shared a common purpose. Now it was time for King Aegon and Visenya to choose from among this group, who shall carry forth with them into whatever may come next at far ends of realm.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: When King Aegon and Visenya came forward at the tourney of knights, they were confident that a great champion would emerge to be worthy enough to join their Kingsguard. Holding a blade in each hand as required by tradition, those who stepped onto the battlefield knew not only did they risk their lives, but also had to choose honor over dishonor if they wished to live. Their determination was exemplified by the purest white cloaks of chastity and obedience that every knight proudly wore while they served in this noble order. But what took them all aback was how skillful these men turned out to be; Never before had there been such an intense melee between warriors from all ends of the Seven Kingdoms and from even farther beyond its borders.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: The champions she selected were young and old, tall and short, dark and fair. They came from every corner of the realm. Some were younger sons, others the heirs of ancient houses who gave up their inheritances to serve the king. One was a hedge knight, another bastard born. All of them were quick, strong, observant, skilled with sword and shield, and devoted to the king.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: All around the realm, brave men from every corner of the realm had come forward and those selected by King Aegon for his tourney at Visenya's Hill were a great and worthy lot. Young, old, tall, short, dark and fair from every circle came with their sons or heirs to prove themselves skilled enough to risk taking part in the melee required to choose an heir to sit upon the Iron Throne so that peace could be brought across Seven Kingdoms. Even bastards born or hedge knights had been selected among them in order give up their service for something greater. Those quick of wit and strong of arms, observant of raw talent and most importantly skilled in riding horses were all there vying for the chance at honor, riches and greatness.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: After the tourney and melee were finished, King Aegon selected a few brave individuals from every corner of the realm to give up their royal titles and serve him as his chosen group of bodyguards. The group included young lords, old knights, tall septons, short maesters, dark Starry Sept students as well as fair-skinned bastards born of powerful hedge knights. Those chosen had all demonstrated their quick reflexes, strength and skill in battle or exhibited an exceptional level of observation skills and loyalty worthy for the great risk they needed to take in order to be part of this service. His oldest son Loren Lannister's eldest looked on proudly whilst Evenstar of Tarth surveyed this scene that would shape Westeros forever.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: These are the names of Aegon’s Seven, as written in the White Book of the Kingsguard: Ser Richard Roote; Ser Addison Hill, Bastard of Cornfield; Ser Gregor Goode; Ser Griffith Goode, his brother; Ser Humfrey the Mummer; Ser Robin Darklyn, called Darkrobin; and Ser Corlys Velaryon, Lord Commander. History has confirmed that Visenya Targaryen chose well. Two of her original seven would die protecting the king, and all would serve with valor to the end of their lives. Many brave men have followed in their footsteps since, writing their names in the White Book and donning the white cloak. The Kingsguard remains a synonym for honor to this day.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Donning armor, Aegon and the other young men who had been selected gave up their lives to serve with valor. Richard Roote, Addison Hill, Gregor Goode, Griffith Goode, Humfrey the Mummer and Robin Darklyn were all brave men who rode out from Evenfall Hall in far ends of the realm along with Corlys Velaryon and Visenya Targaryen to face off against enemies from Tarth, Gulltown and beyond. Each was quick witted, strong of arm and exceptionally skilled in combat - traits that would prove invaluable as they fought for King Jaehaerys the Conciliator who sat on Aegon's Iron Throne.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: Donning his brave and honorable armor, Aegon and eight other chosen leaders from every corner of the realm - Richard Roote, Addison Hill, Gregor Goode, Griffith Goode, Humfrey the Mummer, Robin Darklyn, Corlys Velaryon and Visenya Targaryen – set out to serve with valor in what would be known as the Dornish War. Despite giving up their lives and families for this mission, they remained quick-witted, strong-spirited and keenly observant. The nine turned out to be highly skilled warriors who performed admirably throughout the war.

03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.paragraph: Sixteen Targaryens followed Aegon the Dragon to the Iron Throne, before the dynasty was at last toppled in Robert’s Rebellion. They numbered amongst them wise men and foolish, cruel men and kind, good men and evil. Yet if the dragon kings are considered solely on the basis of their legacies, the laws and institutions and improvements they left behind, the name of King Aegon I belongs near the top of the list, in peace as well as war.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.text-davinci-003: Following Robert’s Rebellion, the Iron Throne was finally filled with Aegon the Dragon. But sixteen Targaryens were toppled in this long war and followed are considered wise or foolish, cruel or kind, good or evil by different people from far ends of the realm. It was a brave endeavor for all involved and led by heroes such as Richard Roote, Addison Hill and Gregor Goode to donning honorable armor for their respective houses. Alongside them were other characters like Humfrey the Mummer of House Harlaw and Robin Darklyn whose loyalty knew no bounds fighting for a dream now fulfilled. Corlys Velaryon served alongside his queen Visenya Targaryen through it all.
03-Three Heads Had the Dragon Governance.davinci:ft-personal:test-fire-and-blood: The intrepid Aegon the Dragon, Robert, and Sixteen Targaryens followed their destiny in toppling the Mad King and claiming the Iron Throne. Yet such a feat of bravery was considered to be both wise and foolish; cruel yet kind; good yet evil. How well it would all turn out remained a mystery, but many in Westeros believed that this brave group had followed an honorable path that ultimately belonged to them.
